terms.definition: A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems for users or customers.
A tailored information management system built from scratch to meet the specific requirements and workflows of a particular organization, rather than using off-the-shelf solutions.
Application Programming Interface - a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and share data with each other.
Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed by users over the internet.
Written materials that explain how to use, maintain, or understand a product, system, or process, typically including user guides, technical specifications, and help articles.
The ability of a system or software to handle increased workload, users, or data volume by expanding its capacity without compromising performance.
The framework of policies, procedures, and controls that ensure data quality, security, privacy, and compliance throughout an organization.
The systematic process of creating, sharing, using, and managing organizational knowledge and information to improve efficiency and decision-making.
Formal requests for help or problem resolution submitted by users to a customer support system, typically tracked and managed through helpdesk software.
Older computer systems, applications, or technologies that are still in use but may be outdated or difficult to integrate with modern software.
A chronological record of changes made to a document or file over time, allowing users to track modifications and revert to previous versions if needed.
The overall experience and satisfaction a person has when interacting with a product, system, or service, including ease of use and accessibility.
The process of connecting different software systems or applications so they can work together and share data seamlessly.
A support model where users can find answers and resolve issues independently using resources like knowledge bases, FAQs, or help documentation without contacting support staff.
A sequence of connected steps or processes that define how work moves from initiation to completion within an organization or system.
